item.description:

item.title: Week 27 #Weeknotes: July 8 -14, 2024
item.description:
Despite the ongoing struggle to wrangle weekly updates, I’m back in the saddle again. Persistence, it seems, is the key to consistent victories, both in writing and in life.

Work Front: The Enterprise Software Development Rollercoaster

Persistence rings especially true in my work in product development and delivery. I continue to grapple with a set of issues that, over my 15-year career, feel both repetitive and wicked. These challenges, while engaging and intellectually stimulating, follow a cyclical pattern: a period of rapid development to meet immediate revenue goals, followed by a phase of simplification and unification. Build, then tidy—rinse and repeat.

item.title: S2E11 #Weeknotes Mar 11-17 '24
item.description:
Crikey, this week’s been good, both at the office and at home. Let’s unpack the highlights:

The Work Front

Nearly 5-ish months in the deep end covering for my boss, Vice-President, PMO – what a ride! I’ve been reflecting on the impact I’ve made and how to keep that momentum going across different projects.

Speaking of big-picture stuff, we’ve kicked off the 3-year planning exercise. This is essentially a roadmap for the next three years, helping us chart our course and prioritise initiatives. Companies do this for a few reasons: to anticipate future trends, ensure alignment across departments, and make sure we’re all rowing in the same direction. The process itself usually involves a mix of top-down direction and bottom-up input – think strategy sessions with senior leadership and feedback loops from individual teams.

item.title: S2E10 #Weeknotes Mar 04-10 '24
item.description:
Looking back on the week, it’s been a whirlwind of activity both professionally and personally. Let’s dive into the highlights:

Professional Reflections:

As you know, the economic landscape has been undergoing some seismic shifts lately. With the end of the era of “free money” and the closure of zero interest rate policies, businesses are feeling the squeeze. In the tech industry, where costs often took a backseat to other revenue streams, there’s now a renewed focus on the bottom line. The talk of the town revolves around layoffs, potential recessions, and the need for prudent financial management.

item.title: S2E09 #Weeknotes Feb 26-Mar 03, '24
item.description:
2024 is already rolling, and this past week provided a handful of experiences that will definitely stick with me. Let’s jump right in!

SOFEA and the community spirit: My organisation, Informa, runs a fantastic initiative by offering employees four days of paid volunteer leave to contribute to a cause of their choice. As we began the year, I looked for ways our technical program management team could bond outside of work. Brainstorming another project solution didn’t feel right, so using a day to support a local charity was a clear choice.

item.title: S2E08 #Weeknotes 19-25 Feb'24
item.description:
Meta reflections on writing these #weeklynotes

While the underlying purpose has always been “to reflect on the past week, to go forward into the next week with intentions”, I dabbled with multiple formats for writing these #weeknotes. I might never settle on one format, but I am drawing back on the inspiration from Philippa Perry’s book, “How to Stay Sane”, for the foundational principles: that to remain stable yet flexible, coherent and yet able to embrace complexity, and to thrive in this world, these #weeknotes help me in: a) self-observation, b) relating to others, c) managing stress (as the right kind of stress creates positive stimulation), and d) listening/amending the personal narrative. While I chop the reflections into personal/work boxes, the key themes are the same.

item.description:

  4. Best Practices for Leading and Managing Retrospectives:

Technical programme management and product execution is a practice. We develop our skills by doing the work regularly and repeatedly: one project, one feature, one service at a time. All of us know that to improve, we need to learn from our previous experience and build on from there. Each framework, method, playbook in execution has in its core ways a principle to inspect and adapt.  Here’s a framework that I refined over time to conduct these release retrospectives effectively. Original inspiration comes from: Agile Retrospectives by Esther D and Diana L.

item.title: The Art of Launching a Tech Program: My 15-Year Playbook
item.description: Fifteen years ago, a simple question from my boss ignited a flame that still burns bright: “Can you make this idea fly?” That “idea” became my first foray into the exhilarating world of technical program management (TPM), a journey that has since woven its way through over 40 tech projects and a dozen intricate, multi-team programs. From nimble startups to sprawling enterprises, I’ve learned that while contexts may differ, the bedrock of success lies in a meticulous “set-up” phase. This isn’t a rigid checklist, but rather a playbook honed through experience, designed to de-risk delivery and unlock early learning. So, gather around, fellow journeymen, and let’s delve into the secrets that unlock high-flying tech programs.

item.title: Employing System Thinking to Technical Programme Management
item.description: Embarking on the integration of WeChat Pay for our Chinese customers was not just a project; it was a riveting exploration of dependencies, interconnections, and the intricate dance of technology in a dynamic ecosystem. This journey demanded more than conventional project management—it required a masterclass in systems thinking. In this playbook, we unravel the saga and distil the lessons learned into actionable insights for fellow technology program managers.

item.title: S01E03: #weeknotes: 16-20 January
item.description:
A Smooth Transition into 2023: Quarterly Planning, Insights, and Dune

The year 2022 concluded with the same energy and flavor as its preceding months, but 2023 carries an undercurrent of solidity and assurance. As we navigate the early weeks of this new year, several key themes have emerged, shaping my focus and approach.

Quarterly Planning: Inceptions and Construction Beginnings

The beginning is always delicate. As we embark on this quarter’s planning, Dune’s profound quote resonates deeply: “Beginnings are delicate. They must be nurtured like small flames.” We must carefully consider our goals, strategies, and resource allocation, ensuring that every initiative ignites with the potential to flourish.

item.title: Notes from the week: 2-6 January
item.description: Philippa Perry wrote a very useful book, “How to Stay Sane”, which I am reading currently, and the first step that Philippa recommends is to allocate time for self-reflection (along with a prescribed format to do that reflection - the remainder of the post is loosely based on that prescription). Now, however, we all know that self-reflection is something we “need to” do, “love to” do, but at least in my case, never do it enough and/or consistently. Coincidentally, I have been a fan of the weeknotes that Jonny Williams has been publishing throughout the last year and I found them a useful format to not only reflect but to share the notes from the world. There’s intentionality in it and also a social commitment that I love. So, here we go: here’s the first of the 2023! Oh, wishing you a happy new year, by the way (if I can still wish you on the 09th of Jan).
